elements.text: You will need a large bowl, sand, Magnetic Letters, a plastic scooper, pieces of paper with each child’s name on them (draw a line below the name for children to write their letters), and crayons.
Today we read a book called
. In the book, we met a girl named Ruby and her brothers Oscar Lee, Rodrigo, and José.

In this activity, you will take turns using the scooper to dig for letters. If someone digs up a letter in your name write it down on the line below the letter in your name. Model this for children before you start the activity.
Show the two Picture Cards. Explain that letters can have curves or they can be straight. Give examples of straight and curved letters.
Invite children to take turns using the scooper to dig out a letter. Then have the child say the letter they found and hold it up. Ask:
Is this a letter in your name?
Invite children to write that letter on the line underneath their names if the letter appears in their names.
Continue until all the letters have been found.

Invite children to take turns saying their names and spelling them out for the group. Doing so will reinforce the alphabet and help children remember the letters in their names along with the sequence they appear in. Then have children talk about their names. Ask,
What do you like about your name? Are there any people in your family with the same name?

For younger or developmentally delayed children, sing “The Alphabet Song” with them and write each letter as you sing it. If children are unable to visualize the letter, point to that letter somewhere in the classroom.
Encourage children to write their names on their own using legible letters in proper sequence. Assist where necessary.

For Spanish-speaking children who have a letter in their names that is not in “The Alphabet Song” or for the letters with accents on them write those letters on a piece of paper. Then show children the similar letters that appear in English. For example,
, etc. You may also point out that the Picture Cards show the letters
in American Sign Language. Encourage children to form the letters with their fingers.

Invite children to use crayons, markers, pipe cleaners, clay, etc., to form straight and curved letters. Invite children to talk about the letter they have made. Ask them to look around the classroom to find the same letter.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
You will need wooden blocks: three rectangles, six squares, and two triangles.
by Brenda Maier. We focused on the way Ruby planned and then built her fort. She kept going until she was done. She didn’t give up.

Today we learned that sometimes when you want to build something, things can go wrong. You might not get the help you need. How do you solve that problem? Keep trying different ways of doing it until you get it right.
In this activity, we will use blocks to make a fort. Then we will try to use a different design to build a fort.
Ask children to use the blocks to build a fort.
Have children explain why they built their forts the way they did.
Invite children to try a new design for their fort. Which design do they like better? Why?
Invite children to talk about the two forts they built. Was it hard to try a new design? Was there an item that they couldn’t figure out how to make? How did they solve that problem?
For younger or developmentally delayed children, demonstrate a simple fort design, such as a triangular block on top of a square block.  Then demonstrate a simple alternative way to build a fort.
Invite children to build other items using the blocks you have provided. They can create a rocket, a boat, a train, etc.
Encourage children who speak another language to teach you and the other children in the class how to say
in their first language.   Point out that building words with letters is similar to building forts with blocks. Show which letters are used to build the word

Offer children the option to draw their fort with pencils, crayons, or markers. Be sure to provide many different colors. Encourage children to talk as they draw, using as many describing words as possible.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
You will need The Little Red Fort.
by Brenda Maier. We saw that Ruby had to gather all of the supplies she needed to build her fort.
Let’s revisit these words since they have something to do with today’s activity.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of different items from the book and tell if those were supplies that Ruby gathered to build her little red fort.
Ask children to give a thumbs-up if the picture shows something that Ruby used to build her fort.
Show one Picture Card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Continue the game by showing the next Picture Card.
Invite children to talk about how Ruby used the supplies they saw in the pictures to build her fort.

For younger or developmentally delayed children, use the book to show them where and when the supplies appear in the book. Encourage as much conversation as possible about whether Ruby is using the item in the picture.

For children needing a bit more, challenge them to name something else that could be built with each materials. Encourage children to use as much detail as possible to describe what they could build with each material.

Give children extra time for peer-to-peer conversation. Encourage children to work in pairs, talking about what they see in the pictures. Remind them to take turns speaking, with one person actively listening while the other speaks. Remind children that it’s okay to use all the languages they both know when talking with a peer who is also multilingual.

Helping children focus their attention is a critical learning milestone for preschoolers. You can help children focus their attention through a variety of strategies, including using simple directions and previewing the activity before you begin. Model what to do with each card and check to make sure that all children know what to do.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
and we read about the different materials the three rabbits used to make their houses. One rabbit made a house of straw, another made a house of sticks, and the third rabbit made a house of bricks.
Let’s revisit those words, since they have something to do with the activity we will play today.
Use the sticks and straw Vocabulary Cards to revisit the words.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of objects  made of different materials and try to guess what kind of material they are made of.
Show one Picture Card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Continue the game using the next Picture Card.
Encourage children to talk about all of the different materials they saw on the cards.
Which materials are strong? Which materials are not strong? What other qualities do the materials have that would make them good for building different things?

Point to the building material in each picture as you ask the questions about them. If children are unsure of the names of the materials, provide a sentence with a cloze to help them guess the word—for example,
This table is made of w
Invite children to look at the pictures and think about objects they see and think about what else they can make using those materials.  Encourage children to describe what they would make.
Use repetition to enhance children’s understanding of the vocabulary they need in order to talk about the objects in the pictures. For example, point to the wooden chair and say,
This is a chair. It is made out of wood.
Have children repeat each sentence after you.

Provide clay, craft sticks, pipe cleaners, paper, and Connecting Cubes so that children can build their own creations out of the materials you provide. Children can also choose to draw their creations. Encourage children to use as many describing words as possible when they talk about their creations and the materials they used to build them.
